‘non-duality’, Manj. 87 ttuśāttā ttathatta aśa’ña ‘the void, suchness, unity’, beside K 55,17r4 śā’mña jsa ‘with duality’; K 58, 29r3 cu vara śā’mñä na daittą ‘where duality is not seen’. See duva ‘two’, śäta- ‘second’, later śe’; aśa’ña ‘non-duality’.
‘without holes,knots’Z 23-44, Chinese kien-mi ‘compact’ (K 369.2; 617.2). Base śṷambh- to śṷabh- in O.Ind. śvabhra- ‘hole’, Zor.P. sūrāk ‘hole’.

‘sharp, flinty, stony’,Ⅲ 79.10 bvaiysä aśäjä satharä dūrä ttī jsāṃ sagūḍä ‘ long flinty slope, hard, then also stony’. From as- ‘to be sharp’, IE Pok. 19-20 ak̂-, O.Ind. aśáni- ‘arrow-point, thunderbolt’ (> Khotan Saka lw aśuna-), Greek  ἃκανος‘thorn’. Here *aśan-či- with dialectal -ś- kept. See s.v. śśära- ‘good’.
‘unhurt (?) ’, v 145,11765-6 ///maśā aśūla harya///ga se mū va aśūla///. See aśau’laka ‘unhurt’.

‘plant name, BS kaśeruka-, scirpus kysoor ’ (Lat. scirpus ‘bulrush’), Sid. 18r4. Base *as-ya- ‘sharp, pointed’, to as-:s-‘to sharpen’, with Av. asūra-‘point’, Oss. D. änsurä ‘tusk’, I. ssyr, Sogd.B. ’ns’wr, BS danta- ‘tusk’. IE Pok. 18-22 O.Ind. śiśāti: śita- ‘to sharpen’.

‘unharmed (?)’, Ⅱ 80.12 ṣą mä aysdārä aśau’laka svahaka ‘this my supporter, unharmed (?), safe’. Base zai-:zi- ‘to injure’ with śa’- from zya-, Av. zyāni-, Zor.P. zyān, N.Pers. ziyān. Armen, lw zean. Suffix -laka- as in Sid. 151r1 śikalaka, Tib. legs-par ‘well’, and agalaka ‘ limb ’ to aṃga-. Here dyadic with svahaka-.

‘perhaps’, Ⅲ 70-109 paṃmarai bvīrau aśka ‘perhaps you know a report of her’; v 339, 77r3 aśka auṣṭe gyasta ‘perhaps the deity is angered’, BS G 37, 72b7 deva-krodham hi te bhavet, Tib. rab-tu ‘greatly’. From older asti with ka (Av. asti, kadā). For aśtä ka, note V 333, 27r3 aśtä ko se kuṃjsati t<t>īma pharākä hämäta, BS G 37, 2424 bahūni tasya bījāny utpadyeran. See aścä, aśte ‘is there ...?’.
‘is there...?’, K 32.32 aśte ī ‘is it perhaps. . . ’; v 244, 1b3 pasti sa aścä, =K 94.96 pasta hva sa aśta. . . ‘he spoke saying, Is there. . . ?’; 11 10-161 aścai kaiṇa.
see aśtū.

‘existence’, K 54, I5VI aśti jsa ttuśāttā, naiścä jsa ttūśāttā, =BS samskṛta-śūnyatā, asaṃskṛta-śūnyatā; K 53.9.4-5 aśti naiśte jsa pahaiṣṭä ‘without existence (and) non-existence’; K 67.168-9 aśte jsa aśtu khu jīye ‘how existence is destroyed by existence’; Manj. 320 nai aśta ‘exists not’ (but niśtä ‘is not’). See BS asti-nāsti-bhāvaḥ. From older asti, Tumšuq asti, Av. asti to base ah- (as- before -t-).
‘it is’ with pronoun, Ⅱ 101-244 na ra ma stūrä aśtą na bai’da pamūhą ‘ there is no longer for me beast, not clothes upon me’ (ma. . .aśtą ‘I have’).

‘what’, Ⅲ 123.59 aśtū vai kṣamai, BS kiṃ kṣamati ‘what pleases you?’; Ⅱ 52.6 parau na ā sa khve tcerai aśtū-ṃ āṃ ya ‘ a command did not come how you (-e) should act, what to do with them (-ṃ) ’; Ⅱ 52.8 pvesīda sa aśtū ā yaṃdą ‘they ask, What are you doing?’; Ⅱ 85*13 viña ra ttā aśtū pharākä ttūśā silāta haṣḍi yine ‘ now also I make report as to many empty words’; II 7*118 aścū gvaṣṭaiysathūā ‘ (what) have you been separated in births ? ’ See also haiśtū.

‘horse’s fodder, lucerne’, Ⅲ 73.184 aśa ra aśpara hvaḍāṃdä ‘the horses ate lucerne’; Ⅱ124.86 aśpara, BS yāṃga asana (? yoga-aśana-); Z 13.91 rrusa aśpari ‘barley, horse’s fodder’; compound Ⅳ, 60a3 aśpara-barā ‘carriers of lucerne’. From *aśśa-para- (early type of compound like biś-paḍā ‘first of all’) to base par- ‘to feed’, pres. pār-: pāḍa- ‘to nourish, rear’. For lucerne Akkadian aspastu, asupastu, aspasti, Kroraina aśpista-, Zor.P.,N. Pers. aspast, Aram, ’spst-’, Syriac ’spst-’, pstst’-, Arab. fuṣṣ, fuṣfuṣah.
‘cavalry’, Manj. 138 aśya hasty a gūha rahya tc(ü)ra- ysanya hīna ‘four-membered army, cavalry, elephants, infantry, chariotry’. Adjective to aśśa- ‘horse’.
‘not attached’, Ⅱ 115.31 BS lw Kroraina aṣajamaṇa, Pali asajjamāna-, BS aṣajyamāna- to base BS ṣang- (O.Ind. sang-) ‘attach’, see the full text s.v. khāśā’nvā.

‘indolence’, K 3, 139v1-2 aṣarrāmata hämäta, Tib. źum-pa ‘fear, despondency’, Chinese hi-tai-sin ‘with indolent mind’(K 366-3; 184-10; 801-1); E. Lamotte, translation ‘ découragement (līna-citta-)’. Base ṣṣarr-, Z 20-8 strīye daha āṣṣuḍa tsīndä ‘women and men go about excited’; Z 7.24 suhäna ṣṣarri klaiśa ‘by pleasure (BS sukha-) triumphs over kleśa-afflictions’. The conjunct ṣṣ -is from š-, χš-,fš-, equivalent to O.Ind. kṣ-, ps-. Possibly O. Ind. psar- archaic equivalent to mad- ‘be excited’ (BSOAS 21, 1958, 543). See also ysīta-, iysīye.

‘pigeon’ Z 20.16 tcīrauka daindä duva assänaka ‘two ducks are seen, pigeons’; JS 34r2 aṣṇake;  Ⅱ 80.25 aṣanai; Sid. 17r5 āṣai aṣṇai, BS hārīta-, Tib. phug-ron sŋon-po ‘blue pigeon’, plural Ⅲ 35.32 aṣṇā; compound Sid. 142v4 aṣṇūha ‘ dung of pigeons’ (*axśaina-gūθa-). To Oss. D. äxsinängä, DI. äxsinäg ‘dove’ (TPS 1945.6); Tokhara B ekṣinek in the adjective ekṣinekaṃñana misa ‘flesh of pigeon’. See also āṣṣeiṇa- from *axšaina- ‘blue’.
‘eternal’, K 60, 35r1 askāṃjsya jsīna byehe ‘he gets eternal life’, see oṣkāṃjsya-, āṃṣkāmjsya.

‘untouched’, Z 13-114 cu vara bīnāña aṣkusta adaunda ṣṭāna akrīya ‘what there (=where) music untouched, unblown, unbeaten’; Manj. 414 bīnāña aṣkūstai ṣṭāna pīhyāda ramanī hvara ‘ music untouched, they beat ( = sound) delightful, sweet’, Base skau-:sku- ‘to touch, play a musical instrument’.
‘not saṃskāra- , Manj. 372, negative to ṣkoṅgyā-.
‘not abusing’, V Ⅲ, 33v1 aniyaśśu aṣṭakulcu, BS abhaṇḍana-. See ṣṭakula- ‘abuse’.
‘pigeon’, see aṣṣänaka-.

asamkhista- ‘unsmeared, unpolluted’, Z 6.22 daśyau baśdyau jsa asaṃkhälstu ‘undefiled by the ten sins’; Z 6.39 klaiśyau jsa asaṃkhilstä; K 60,36v2 biśām upakleśā’m vāysañāṃ o’syāṃ asaṃkhistą, ṣṭe ‘is undefiled by all smaller afflictions (BS upakleśa-), in_x005ffluences (BS vāsanā), desires (olsa-)’; Manj. 171 asakhe’sta sakhuja veysa ‘undefiled like the lotus ’; K73.34 asakhista sa khū ji rana ‘undefiled like a jewel’; K 55,17r4 śāṃ’ña jsa asaṃkhistä ṣṭe ‘is undefiled by duality’; K 54, 13v3 svabhāvna asaṃkhistä ‘undefiled by nature’; K59, 31v4 asaṃkhistä ṣṭe avi’hī ‘undefiled it is, unchecked’. Parallel to Pali anulitto lokena toyena padumaṃ yathā ‘ unsmeared by the world as the lotus by water’. See saṃkhal-.
‘completed, v367.151, see uspurra-.
‘foeless’, V 113, 35v1 asānä īṇete hlñe jsa anṛhīyä ‘without enemy, unoppressed by a foreign army’, from negative and sāni ‘enemy’.
‘impure’, Ⅲ 123.66 asūrai, BS aśuci-; Sid. 125vI asurai ‘unclean’, BS amedhya-, Tib. mi gčaŋ. See suraa- ‘pure’ (*suxraka-).
‘not burnt’, Sid. 153v2 khu ri va asuva śau beṣṭarą bāgara harśtä ‘so that one layer of leaf remains unburnt’, Tib. lo-ma naŋ-rim ma ćhig ćam-du bsregs-nas, see sūjs-: sūta-.

‘slow, slow-witted’, equivalent to BS jaḍa-‘foolish’, Z 5.14 hvate balysä hvī’yä ūtamo ysaṃthä käḍe asottāña kyai tta jändä ‘the Buddha taught a parable about human birth (BS upamā); they are very slow who destroy it so’, because hard to reach. From *saub-:sotta- to Sogd. Bud. swδ swδ’n ‘swiftly’, IE Pok. 954 skeu- ‘of speed’, Lit. šáuju, šáuti ‘throw (› shoot)’, šũvis ‘shot’, šáudyti ‘make throw about, shoot often’, O.Slav. sujǫ, sovati ‘shove’. Beside IE Pok. 954 (s)heu- with incre_x005fments, Pok. 955 -bh-, -d-, skeubh- see s.v. anāskotta-, haskautta-, to O.Ind. códati ‘drive, force’, N.Pers. čust ‘swift’. See also biśautta- ‘hackled’ from saub-. Suffix -āna- with -ya-.
‘up’, Ⅲ 70.107 naṇḍa makala aska jsā rruśta ‘the monkey Naṇḍa got the chieftainship’. See uska ‘up’.

‘put back’, Ⅲ 93-261 <da>dä jṣā’ñāñä khu śva’ jīye ttī askināñä paskyāṣṭä hāñāṣṭä, ysūnāñä ‘ so much is it to be cooked that half is gone, then it must be put back into the vessel, it must be strained’. From us- and kan- ‘to place’,

‘arise, issue’, Ⅱ 2.20 askhaṃjsa (SDTV 30); Sid.7v1 iskhajsä, BS abhyudaya- ‘rising’; Ⅱ 123 (4091).6 askhijsye apvenye bāḍä ‘prosperous secure time’; with -āmatā-, III 64-21 askhajsāme, II 85.Ⅱ askhijsāme. See uskhajs-.
see askhauys-.

‘eminence, protuberance’, Sid. 138r4 sai’kä cu askhaukara hame, BS utsedha- ‘protuberance’; Sid. 143r3 ni riysauttä askhaukarīyāvai ri va ni hamä vasve baustä ṣṭe ‘ it no longer flows; also it does not become a protuberance; it is known to be clean’, BS na cotsanna-, Tib. rlo-ba med-pa rnams yin-te (rlo-ba =hphyaŋ-ba ‘hang down’). From us- ‘up’ with base kauk-, as in Lit. kaukarà‘hili’, IE Pok. 589 keu-k-.

‘move up’, Ⅲ 104.44-6 śada ka bīnamīye brrī satta vahanī ā vāvai jīyi drai ai’ha: askhāysī hamāra brra hvanda ugvaysāra avīpa, = Ⅲ 108-4-5 śaṃda ka bīnämāve brrī satta vahanī ā vā vāvai jī<yi drai ai’ha: askh>auysī, hamārä brra sattu gvaysārä avīpa ‘ if the earth should split, the beloved man sink in, or for him life of three stages end; beings become amorous, yet they part assuredly’ (avīpa, BS avikalpaṃ).
‘top’, Sid. I53V4, Tib. śiŋ-buhi thor-to, see ysihe, Tib. thor-to.

‘at last’, Ⅱ 94.16 astaṃ āvą ‘they came at last, = Ⅱ 96.99 ąsta āvą; K 30.205-6 astavai brraạṭā heś(t)ü tta dyāya ‘at last she asked her, Did you see anything?’, = K 38-140 tvāysādi brrastā haiśtū tta dyāyi ‘she asked the old woman, Did you see anything?’. See ustama-.

astān- ‘to stretch’, Ⅲ 34.12-13 khū ja bīna astana ‘as one tunes the hīnā-instrument’, = Ⅲ 36.8 khu ja bīna astāna. Infinitive Ⅲ 40-16 khu bīnä skīdä astāmdä ‘as they touch the bīnā-instrument to tune it’. From us-tan- Av. ustāna- ‘up-stretched’, N.Pers. tanīdan ‘to stretch’, IE Pok. 1065-6 ten- ‘stretch’, O.Ind. tanoti, tatá-, Greekτἀνυται, τείνω, τατός . See also thana-, ttaṃga-, ttanv-.
‘numberless’, Ⅲ 60.35, see haṃkhīysa-.
‘unbroken’, Bcd 48n, BS akhaṇḍa-; ahatcastūm ‘unbroken for me’, Ⅳ 23.8 ahatcastūṃ mūñī ‘may (the vow) remain for me unbroken’. See hatcan-.
‘without hostility’, Ⅴ Ⅲ, 33v1 ahaṃdrūṣṣu aggūrāsu, BS avigrahāya avivādāya. See haṃdrūṣṣa-.
‘without change’, Sid. 7r5 ahamici jsai kāña krravī tcerai ‘without change it must be kept, the treatment of it must be carried out’, Tib. mi hgyur-bar bsruŋ-bahi čho-ga byaho. See hamista-.

‘unchanged’, JS 4v1 sūmīrä garä māñamdä ahamistä akhāṣṭä ‘like Sumeru mountain unchanged, unmoved’; K 63, 78r3 aysmū ahamistą akhaustä ‘the mind unchanged, unmoved’; Sid. 7v1 cuai hauva ahamaista he (variant hame) ‘for whom the strength is unchanged’, Tib. sñiŋ stobs ni mi hgyur-ba byed-pa-ste.
‘abusive’, JS 8v4 ahamñe ysīre hve ttrikṣa salāta ‘abusive, harsh, sharp words he spoke’. From Prakrit to adhimanya-.

‘undisturbed’, SuvP. 60v2 śye ṣīvi ahaṃphiḍä śāna, hūña dyai haḍara ba’ysa, BS eka-rātram atandritena svapnāntaraṃ gataṃ mayā ‘one night lying undisturbed I saw in a dream former Buddhas’. See haṃphīr-.

‘unsuitable’, Sid. 8v4-5 ahaṃbusana hvaḍa khaṣṭa patsāñä ‘unsuitable foods and drinks must be avoided’, Tib. kha-zas mi hphrod-pa de-dag spaŋs-la; Sid. 8v4 ahaṃbusanāṃ hvadāṃ khaṣṭāṃ jsa. See haṃbusana-.

‘not arisen, non-extant’, K 112.381 cu baiśa hara ahamya bvādai ‘who may know all dharma-elements to be non-existent’; Manj. 2 ahamye aje naṣau’da ‘non-existent, not perished, quietened’. Older ahämäta-.

‘without trouble’, v 113, 35r1 (dyadic) ahaysgamatu u anuvadräta hämāre, BS anupasargāṇy anupāyāsāni ca; v 113, 35v1 u ahaysgamatä ahvarīysätä (variant aharīysätä), BS anupasargaṃ cānupāyāsaṃ ca. See haysgamata.
‘unwashed’, Ⅲ 85.75 ahaysnāva ysaraṃjsą, Ⅲ 90.182 ahaysnāvä ysaraṃjsä ‘unwashed safflower (carthamus tinctorius)’. See haysnāta-.
‘unpresented’, Ⅳ 55a2 aharaṣṭa ysārä drrai-se haudā mūri ‘not presented, 1370 mūrā-coins’. See haraṣṭa-.

‘with none left out, total’, Bcd 50v1 aharīna, BS aśeṣatah, Sid. 130r1 beti jsa āchā aharīna biysānā harbeśä jidä ‘dispels all severe diseases arising from wind’, Tib. rluŋ-nad-kyis ñam-thag-pa thams-čad sel-ba yin-no; v 247, 14b1 aharīna, BS sakala-samāpta-.
‘total’, Sid. 133r3 cu buri saṃ aharīnaka vā-śerū hamāte ‘whatever may be total gout (BS vāta-śoṇita-)’, Tib. dreg-go-čog-la ni.
‘without trouble’, BS anupāyāsa-, reported as a variant to v 113, 35v1 ahvarīysätä.

‘uninterrupted’, Sid. 146v5 aharṣṭä bijsāñä, Tib. rgyun-tu blugs-na, ‘to be poured without stopping’; Bcd 49v3 aharṣṭa, BS sarve ‘all’. Later ahaṣṭa-, Ⅲ 127.7 ahaṣṭa sakra varttai ‘he continuously practises reverence (BS satkriyā-). See harṣṭa-.
‘indigestion’, Sid. 12v3, = v 322.126 apahä.
‘you’, JS 8v1, see uhu.
‘not forgetting’, v 185, 2b4 kye byātarji ahāmurji vä<tä>, dyadic.
‘not forgetfulness’, K 2, 135v2-3 ahāmurgyatete käḍanai; K 7, 148r4 ahāmurgyatetīnā päga’, Tib. mi brj̆ed-pahi stobs ‘power of not forgetting’. See ahaumaurrjä, From hāmura-.

‘quarry, wild beast’, Ⅲ 68.79 ssa-tci’ṃma’ña ahāvi jsyāṃde ‘they killed the 100-eyed quarry’, parallel Rāmāyana mṛgān ‘deer’. From ah- ‘to shoot’, *ahāta- ‘to be shot’, like hasūra- ‘quarry’ from *fra-saura- ‘to be hunted ’, and jsīñaa- ‘ to be slain, criminal condemned’.

‘plant name’, Ⅲ 92.238 ū ahi: ṣi’ vą dāttä ‘the ahi: plant, that is the dāttä-plant’; Ⅰ 183, 102r5 dāttī, BS daṃttī (dantī); Sid. 14r4 dattä hīya bāta ‘root of danti-’, BS danti-, Tib. dandahi rća-ba (rća-ba ‘root’). Possibly ahi- to base ah- ‘to cut’ hence ahi: ‘cutting tool’, as mechanical translation of BS danti(n)- ‘toothed, jagged’ (as khuysaa- for BS mandūkī, and hva-khāṃdala- for BS āruka- from āru- ‘boar’). Then base anh-:ah- ‘to cut’, ahi- ‘cutting tool, sword’, to Av. aŋhū- (ablative Yašt 13.46 aŋhuyāṯ) and O.Ind. así- ‘sword, knife’, Lat. ēnsis ‘sword’ (where base anh- is like kart- ‘to cut’, Av. karəta- ‘sword’, see kāḍara-). BS danti(n)- is baliospermum montanum.
‘non-existent’, Z 9.26 ahämäta dharma, = Manj. 404 ahaimye. From hämä- ‘to become’.

‘not one’s own’, K 154.41-2 ahīye hera nāsāmi ‘taking not one’s own’, the BS śikṣāpada- command adattādāna- ‘taking things not given’; Z 12.64 ihivī heḍä ‘he gives not his own’. See i- =a- negative, and hivī.
‘not greed ’, v 38, 28b3 ///-ä ahīsa naunda himā<te?>/// See hīsa-.
‘you’, Ⅲ 21, 6a2 ahu jsa ‘by you’, see uhu.

‘unnumbered’, K 5, 142v3 ahumāru uy<sn>ora puñīnei nasta bāgyä handajāñätemä ‘I made unnumbered beings to ripen good roots of merit’, Tib. sems-čan maŋ-po dag dge-bahi rća-ba-la yos-su smin-par byas-so; K 2, 137v1 u ahumāru ṣä cu ne sīte śtä ‘uncounted that which he has not learnt’; v 156, 187v2 ahumāryau haysgamaty<au> ‘with unnumbered troubles’; Ⅰ 252, 1r5 <a>humāryau sīyau yseryau, BS śata-sahasra-; SuvO. 68v2 ahumāryau yseryau, BS sahasraneka. From mar-, ṣumar- ‘to count’, ṣumuḍa- ‘counted’.
‘elsewhere’, Manj. 222-3 mare mīḍe ahūlaña hīśta ‘he dies here, elsewhere he migrates’. See uholaña.

‘gourd’, Ⅱ 1.8 ahauḍa vastya; Sid. 18r2-3 ahoḍa, BS alabu-, Tib. ku-ba; Ⅲ 88.153 ttīrä ahauḍä hīya ṣarä ‘nut of bitter gourd’. See also byāra- BS ervāru-. Base vart- ‘to be round’, hence aha-vṛt-a-, with ūḍāra- ‘crystal’ and Waxī wurt, Kurd. bard ‘stone’ (JRAS 1955, 22), naming the gourd ‘round like the belly’.
‘not a gift’, Ⅲ 9,18r3 ttädi( = ttaṃdi) ahaura hauḍai ‘you gave such non-gifts’ beside Ⅲ 10, 19r5 hauri nä hauḍemä ‘I did not give a gift’. See base hor- ‘to give’.

‘weak’, Ⅴ 116, 65r7 ahovana u duṣpäta’, BS sudurbala-; later Ⅰ 163, 79r1 ysāḍa paskyāṣṭi cist a padīmi ahauvaṃ pijsa padīmi ‘it makes the old young again, it makes the weak strong’ (pijsa = päta’jsa-), See haut-, hot- ‘be able’.

‘noose’, Ⅴ 161, 35v2 ///ahväna baittä ‘is bound with a noose’, BS na ca sa tṛṣṇā-pāśa-baddho bhaviṣyati, Tib. sred-pahi źags-pas (BS pāśa-) bčiŋs-par mi hgyur-ro ‘he is not bound by the noose of desire’. See aha-, aha’-, inst. plur. ahyau. For -hv- note also ahva-, aha- ‘belly’.

‘belly’, as first component in ahva-rīysa- ‘fear’ from rrīys- ‘to tremble’ and ahva- ‘belly’, as the source of ‘fear’. See aha ‘belly’, and rrīys- ‘to tremble’. The meaning is from the use of a name of part of the body for the affection in that part, as O.Pers. uši ‘intelligence’ from uš- ‘ear’, Av. karəna- ‘ear’ and ‘deaf’, like Georgian qur-i ‘ear’ qru ‘deaf’, Megrel ‘uru ‘foolish’; Greek ἰσχἰον ‘hip’, ἰσχιἀς ‘pain in the hip’. Hence O.Pers. afuvā- ‘fear’, O.Ind. ápvā-, apvā ‘fear’, from the source ‘belly’. Note Al-Tha‘ālibī, Histoire, ed. H. Zotenberg 714 fa ashala ’l-xaufu baṭana-hu ‘and fear loosened his belly’. Similarly O.Ind. śaṣkulī ‘ear’, and ‘disease of hearing’.
‘not to be spoken’, in 73.188 mire a ahvañe ṣṭāna ‘I shall die since it is not to be spoken’. Base hvan- ‘to speak’, hvaña- ‘to be spoken’.
‘before eating’, Ⅰ 167, 83r4 ahvaḍāṃdī tharka masi hviri ‘as much as a walnut is to be eaten before taking food’. Base hvar- ‘to eat’.
‘not man’, Ⅴ 308, 9r1, BS amanuṣya- in the series from gods to goblins.
‘not men’, Ⅴ 257.6, 1b4 <hva>ndä ahvandä uvāra ‘men, not men, noble ones’. See hvand- ‘man’.
‘belly-shaking, fear’, SuvO. 4v2 haysgamata īyä o kā’ṣca u vadrava īyo gārīvä o puvaṇä o ahvarīysä īyä, BS śokāyāse ’py anarthe ca bhaya-vyasana eva ca, here corresponding to bhaya- ‘fear’. See aha-.

‘lack of fear’ (variant aharīysätä quoted by S. Konow, ed. to Ⅴ 113, 35v1). Possibly a subscript small a added before hva, hardly visible on the photograph, but reported by Konow. The scribe may have intended a- ‘not’ before ahva-rīysätä (instead of an- as in a-uysānā) or has wrongly written hva for -ha- in aharīysa- ‘not trembling’. The ending -ätä may represent either the suffix -ita-, or stand for -ä, as in Ⅴ 77, 145v5 viysäte ‘lotus’ for viysä, with buśānätai ‘scented’ for buśānai.

‘not produced, eternal’, Ⅲ 128.2-3 śukye ahvyāñe saṃtsāru baṃdani-śāl<e?> guchāme udiśāyi ‘for escape from the universal (one = universal) eternal transmigrational prison’. For the ‘prison’, v 126, b1 saṃtsārūṃ bārmina, BS saṃsāra-bhava-bandhanāt, Tib. lćon-ra, Tokhara B saṃsārṣṣe pele, and Jaina saṃsāra-cāraya-. Base hau-:hu- ‘to bear young’, hence parallel to BS aja- ‘not produced’ (see also ahämäta- ‘not arisen’); Av. hunu- ‘son’, hazaŋrō.huna-, haota-, hunahi, hunāmi, O.Ind. sū́te, sūtá-, sūnú-, Zor.P. hunušakēnītan, višūtakān, Form hvya-, as dvya- ‘to beat’, base dav-, IE Pok. 913-14 seu-:sū̆-. See also ṣū ‘son’.

‘or’, I 189, 111r2 rīysūtcana khāśā’ña ā mākṣī hīyi uca jsa ‘to be drunk with rice-water or with honey water’; JS 5r2 śägä (for śaṃgä) ā vā ṣvīdä, ā mīrāhīja karāśä a vā bora ‘conch, or milk or pearl spray or snow’. With vā also, Sid. 102r4 ā vā ṣvīnai ā vā hīśanai yaṃdrrä padīmāñä ‘a tool (BS yantra-) must be made either of horn or of iron’, Tib. rva ham, lčags-kyi sbubs. This ā replaces older o, au ‘or’ either as dialectal difference or phonetic development (cf. also loc. plur. -vo’, replaced by -vā) (to IE Pok. 75), Ⅳ 2.5 ā ni ‘or not’, see o ne.

‘he came’, participle = preterite 3 sing., from *āgata-, older ātä nom. sing. Ⅳ 6oa2 parau ā, ‘the command came’, fem. sing. Ⅱ 89.48 hīna āta ‘the army came’; plur. Ⅱ 126.19 hvaṇḍä āva, older Z 24.473 āta hämāre ‘they came’. Base gam-:gata-, IE Pok. 464-5 gu̯em-.

‘not’ in the word Sid. 5r2 āhvarai ‘sour’, Tib. skyur-ba, fem. Sid. 4v2 āhvarrja, Tib. skyur-ba, BS amla-, from hvara- ‘sweet’. The reverse is in Sogd. Man. n’mryẖ ẕ̆’r ‘sweet poison’; čn šhr’ n’mrtr ‘sweeter than sugar’ (W. B. Henning, BBB 45), from *an-āmra- ‘not sour’. See haṃga- from *am(a)ka- ‘sour’, to IE Pok. 777-8 om-. The short initial a- is replaced by ā- also in āṣṣeiṇa- ‘blue’.
‘towards’, preverb, see ācana, āta, āspar- and others; Av. ā-, a-, O.Ind. ā-, IE Pok. 280-1.
‘you’, suffixed pronoun, older -ū. See J. M. Dresden, Jātaka-stava, p. 412.
‘he came’, JS 34r3, see ā.
‘with thumb’, Z 22.305 inst. sing, from *anguštya-, beside haṃguṣṭa- ‘finger’, see āṣṭī.
‘painful’, Sid. 103r2 khaysma ākrre herä hame ‘abscess becomes a painful thing’, Tib. ñam-thag-pa byed-pahi phol-mig hbyuŋ-ste. From base (s)kar- ‘to cut’ to ā-(s)kṛta- or ā-(s)kṛya-.

‘they begin’, Z 24.499; 3 sing. Z 4.15 ākṣūtä, Ⅲ 83.25 ākṣū jīye ‘begins to vanish’; Sid. 142r5 ākṣu byaśde’ ‘begins to mature’, Tib. ćha-ba-la; pret. Z 5.26 ākṣutte, 3 plur. SuvO. 68v7 bīnāña ākṣuttāndä yanä, BS pravādayanti ‘they began to sound music’; Manj. 405 ākṣya (ya = ü) daitta ‘he begins to see’ = Z 9.27 ākṣüti däyāna; ‘be seen’, Ⅲ 79.11 ragya jsä ākṣūṃ pāstāgä ‘from the bank I was tossed headlong’. See also nikṣūtä, nakṣautta-, kṣäv-, kṣautta-, prakṣautta-. Base xšaub- ‘to disturb’, Av. xšufsa-, M.Pers.T. ’’šwb ‘disturbance’, wšwb-, wyšwb-, wswb’g (He. Verbum 184; Mir.Man. 2.54); Zor.P. āšōp, āšuftak, višōpišn, višuftan, Armen, lw apšop, ašop, N.Pers. āsōb, āšuftan, gušuftan, Balōčī šufaγ ‘to thresh’, šufaγ, šupta ‘be angry’; IE Pok. 625 kseubh-, O.Ind. kṣobh-, kṣubh-; Slav. Pol. chybać ‘move to and fro’ (variants -bh- and -p-),

‘movement, behaviour’, K 4, 142r3 <pra>cīga-saṃbuddhānu ākhośä dyāñätemä ‘I showed the behaviour of the pratyeka-saṃbuddhas’, Tib. spyod-lam ( = BS īryāpatha-). See khauś- ‘agitate’, Ⅴ 340, 80r5 ākṣutte khauśä ‘began to move’, BS G 37, 75a7 vāta-kṣobhena, verbal khauśā’ña, akhauṣṭa-, khoys- ‘move’.

‘covering, layer’, Ⅲ 90. 196 śī pau hīye ājve ‘the layers of the white onion’. From ā-juvā- or ā-judā-, base gau-: gu- or gaud-: gud- ‘cover’. For gau- note Waxī gaw-：gott- ‘to cover’, infinitive gīn ‘to cover’, prigīn ‘horse-cloth’; Sarīkolī parwein ‘horse-cloth’, parway-: parwid ‘to cover’. For gaud-, see uysgun-.
‘silver’, JS 4v1, see āljsata-; adj. ā,jsīja JS 6v4.

‘covered’, Ⅲ 38.41 spyakyau ājsava ‘covered with flowers’, = Ⅲ 40.17 spyakyau ājsävä, = Ⅲ 47.62 spyakyau ājsavä. From ā with ǰata- ‘put, strike’, or čata- from kan- ‘cover’ (see kangā-). See also najsata-, nijsava- ‘covered, set with’, ājsan-.
‘they deck’, Ⅲ 43.21 ālagāryau jsa śaikä aṃga ājsänīdä ‘they deck well the limbs with ornaments (BS alaṃkāra-Y. Base ǰan- or čan- ‘to cover’. See ājsava-.

‘with bonds’, Manj. 204 hṣaṇy(au) ājsyau jsa pabasta nāsākū aysmva pāja ‘bound by momentary bonds the receiver in fact (-ū) is the individual mind’. From base arg- or ark- ‘to restrict, confine, restrain’ see cognates s.v. ai,jsvā (loc. plur.) ‘bonds’. Instead of kṣaṇya a reading kūṇḍa was printed.
‘is to be seated’, K 8, 306, 5r3 ramaṃdai āñä ‘must sit delighted’. See āh- ‘to sit’.

‘flour’, Sid. 133r1, Tib. phye, Sid. 142 VI ārä (-r- for -ḍ-), BS śaktu-; 2nd component Sid. 143r2 rrūsāḍä ‘barley flour’, Ⅲ 85.76; 86.87 rüsādä, in phrase Ⅱ 23.19.2 rruśi jsa āḍi. Base ar- ‘to grind’ see ārr- ‘to grind’. For ‘flour’, the participle ā-rta-, -ka-, here āḍa- (either *arəta- or ā-rta-), Zor.P., Yaγn. ārt, N.Pers. ārd, Pašto ōṛə masc. plur., Wazīrī Pašto ǟṛə ‘dough’, Yidγa yāṛë, yōrəy (*ārtaka-), Šuγnī yāuγǰ, Sarikolī yoγǰ, yowǰ, Sanglēčī wuḷōk, Parāčī wâṛun (*ārtana-). O.Ind. aṭṭa-, Hindī āṭā, Kroraina aṭa, from *alta- (T. Burrow, BSOAS 35, 1972, 539).

‘flour’, Sid. 134V2 mau jsa āḍe jsa grauśe, padīmāñä ‘a paste is to be made from mau-liquor, from flour’, BS snigdhā madyena śaktavaḥ, Tib. čhaŋ hol-kon-gyi skyo- mar byas-pahi naŋ-du (skyo-ma ‘pap, paste, dough’) ed. Pekin 216a3-4. To āḍa-.

‘more wild, raging around’, Ⅲ 70.120 ādara makala hamāre ‘the monkeys are more wild’ (when they fail to find Sītā though under threat of the pulling out of their eyes); K 65, 83r4 bayastām jsīmau āḍarau vaska ‘for the fear-filled ghosts (jsīmaa- =BS preta-}, more wild, (may I get āryāvalokiteśvara’s power)’. Parallel to K 64, 8IV3 ttyā vaską harbäśą dūkha bauḍa īnīme, cū vā ṣai jsīmā āräḍa bayista ‘for those may I be able to bear all woes, even those who are ghosts, wild, fear-filled’. Hence āḍara- from *āra-tara- (if not changed from āraḍa-) to Sogd. ”r’k *āraka- ‘mad’, Av. ara-, Oss. ärra ‘wild, mad’, see also arājsa, arā-bū. But āraḍa-, āräḍa- is the later form of ārragäḍa- ‘evil-doing, guilty’.
‘other’, loc. sing. K 45.22 āḍāña ysītha ‘in another birth’, with secondary ā- from a-, see aḍara, aḍāra- other ’.
Z 4.60 ‘weapon’, see ātaṇa-.
‘sitting’, SuvO. 56v6 dharma-bhānānu vätä āṇānu hā ttä vara tsuñau, BS dharma-āsana-gatānām antikam upasaṃkrameyuḥ. See āh-.
(āṃṇaka?), Sid. 17r3 ‘quail-like bird’, BS vartīra-, Tib. hur-pa, possibly named ‘reddish’ as a colour name from *āṣṇa-, *ārṣṇa- to *ā-raxšna-, with rrāṣa-, N.Pers. raxš.
aṇamdaa- sitting’, see āh-.

‘being in’, BS -vihārin-, Ⅲ 23, 18b2 jau-nisāmä āṇadā ‘being free from strife’, (gen. plural) BS araṇā- vihāriṇāṃ-, ibid. I8b4 araṇā-vyihārai biśä-pīrmāttama ‘being in strifelessness, of all foremost’; ibid. 19a1 araṇä cu samāhāña āṇadai ‘who without strife dwells in a trance’ (BS samādhāna-). See ānandaa-, s.v. āh- ‘sit’.

‘come’, participle, masc. sing. ātä, later ā above, fem. sing, āta (Ⅱ 89.48 hīna āta ‘the troop came’), masc. plur. K 137.914-15 cī vara āta himya tti... sādhukārä hauḍāmdä ‘when they had come, they uttered the (words) good, good’; Ⅱ 96-94 mara vā ttūśā āvä ‘here they came empty’; Ⅱ 126.19 hvaṇḍä āva ‘men came’; 1 sing, v 381, 3v4 ātūmä, N 332, 24v5 ātumä ‘I came’, BS G 37, 21b6 anuprāpta-ḥ, Ⅳ 25.7.9 hāysa ātum ‘I have come far’; Ⅱ 68, 143a6-7 khu vā birgaṃdara āṃna ātū ‘I have come from Birgarṃdara’. In a document āva is for ‘amount to’, Ⅱ 110.13-14 dvī pveca u śā jsā vā heysda āva ‘they have at present amounted to two coverings and also one’: ibid. 19 pātca vā pvaica āva dvī heysde ‘then the coverings have amounted at present to two ’; ibid. 27 āśī hīye vā pveca āva drraye ‘ the coverings of the āṛya-monk amount to three’; ibid. 29-30 pātca vā āśī, hīya pveca āva śā. From *āgata-, base gam-:gata-, Av. gata-, γəmata-, Zor.P. āmat ﹤*ā-gmata-, IE Pok. 464-5 gụem-, O.Ind. gam-:gata-, Greek βαίυω, βατós. See pa,jsama-, naljsam-, hajsam-.
‘overflowing’, Z 292.16 dukhinai ttīyä bäśśä ātajsandä tcei,mañi ‘all eyes overflowing then through grief for him’. Base tak- ‘flow’, see cognates s.v. tajs-.

āṇa- ‘a missile weapon’, Z 4.60 ttṛśśūla kāḍare hãlśtä, bādāra ātaṇa u cakra ‘tridents, swords, spears, lances (?), slings (?) and discus’. BS lists show tomara- ‘lance’ which may be bādāra as ‘thrusting weapon’, and bhiṇḍipāla- ‘missile weapon, sling or dart’; Tokhara A has bhiṇḍipāl, Uigur bintipal. From *ā-šana- ‘missile’, to šan- ‘ to throw down, shake down ’, Sogd. šn- ‘to shake’, BS kamp-. See cognates s.v. sāñīndi, =BS patanti. For ‘sling’, note Av. fradaxśanā- ‘sling’, with daxś- ‘throw’, see dīś- ‘throw’, Zor.P. kōpēn from *kaupanya-. For the form note Av. ákana- ‘quiver’, base kan- ‘cover’.

āgama- ‘desire’, plural SuvO. 54v3 mamä ttätä ātama sambajāṃdu, BS sarve cābhiprāyāḥ samṛdhyantu ‘may all my desires be fulfilled’; Z 2.194 āgamu; SudP. 72v1 āvama, BS abhiprāya--, gen. plur. K 90.740 harbiśāṃ ātamāṃ haṃberākä ‘fulfiller of all desires’; K62, 76v4 āva; plur. Manj. 136 āauvama; inst. sing. Ⅲ 129.11 āvaṃni; plur. Ⅲ 137.19 āvama; JS 38v2 āvaṃ. v 64.42 ttyi hvaṃḍi ātaṃ haṃbirūṃ ‘I will fulfil the man’s desire’; loc. sing. Ⅱ 106.131 pacā āśaryāṃ āyīma ‘in desire for the five teachers’, BS pancaka- ‘group of five’. Verbal ātīm-, base ā-kam-.
‘they fall into’, Z 24.168 kye vā pāstuṃgga ātasāre ‘some fall headlong’. Base kas- ‘to fall’, see uskasāte, kaśś-.
‘to turn’, Z 24.500 trāmu ābeistä śśaṃdā samu kho ju cakṛ ‘the earth turns like a wheel’. See baḍ-, baltte, causat. baiś-, from *ā-vṛtsati.

‘whirlpool’, Z 17.13 īse yande ku vā ābei’sa natä ‘makes whirlpools where are the deep whirling places’; inst. plur. JS 15r2 ābe’syau khvīyau vyaulasta bajāṣa ‘sounds horrific with whirlpools, waves’. See ābeistä ‘it turns’, without ā also Z 24.238 bei’sa, loc. sing. Z 24.412 bei’śśa, older v 40, v5 klaiśīnā bei’lsa ‘waves of affliction’.

‘total’, IV 3.14 lyiba’ āma ‘total’ dyadic, Tib. lib ‘all’; II 63.8 lyiba’ āma pajīdä ‘they demand the total’, without āma also II 21, 15a6 lyiba’ pajīdi. From ham-, hāma- ‘all’ without h-, beside hama- ‘all’, haṃgga- ‘total’ from *hamaka-, to M.Pers.T. hm’g, h’m’g, h’m- ‘all’, Zor.P. hamāk, Armen. lw hamak, N.Pers. hamah, Av. hama-. IE Pok. 902-5 sem.

‘we may be’, Z 5.107 ka tä muhu byāta ne āmaṃ ‘if we have not been remembered by you’. The older middle ending -āmane, is later frequently -āmaṃ, as IV 3v1 yanāmaṃ, IV 3v3 himāmaṃ, for older yināmane, himāmane.

‘dwelling-place’, acc. sing. SuvO. 54v4 ā’mato, BS vihāra- v+E3 381, 4a4 ai’metätu; loc. sing. K 1,134VI e’mäta ne biharāre ‘they do not dwell in the dwelling (BS vihar-), Tib. mi gnas-pa, V 140, 92v5 e’mäta; plural V 116, 65v4 dripäṣkala ju kṣīre ā’mate, BS trailokya-maṇḍale; later III 130b2 śira ā’ma byehūṃ ‘ I shall get a good dwelling’ ; Sid. 8r5 āme, JS 19r1 ā’me. From *āhāmatā- to āh- ‘sit, dwell’.
‘dwelling’, JS 13v3 himyai āmunä ‘you became a dwelling’, from ā with mān- ‘to stay, remain, dwell’. See also āmūha-.

‘short’, contrasting with dāra- ‘long’, V 299, 2r1 āmuro jsīno ‘short life’ ; V 297, Mac. a, b4 karma tcamäna hve’ amur<ä> ‘the act (karma) by which a man <gets> a short <life>’. From ā with mura- to Av. mūra- ‘defective’, mūraka- beside dahaka-. IE Pok. 751—3 mū-E5 in Khotan Saka muta ‘dumb’, O.Ind. mū́ka-, Celtic Ir. mut ‘short’, Lat. mutilus, mūtus, Greek μυκός, Norw. mua ‘be silent’.
‘dwelling’, V 286, 7r1 /// yaṃdi āmuhä; JS 15v4 bhāgä āmuhä nāsä ‘take portion, dwelling’; III 82.13 āmūha nāve ‘ took the dwelling ’. From ā with mān- ‘ to stay ’, see also āmunä.

‘possessing’, II 115.22 biśau bvaijsyā āmauna ‘possessed of all virtues’, parallel to II 115.21 biśau bvaijsyā haphau ‘union with all virtues’. From ā with mauna- from māna-, mān- ‘to stay’. But possibly ‘delightful’, if connected with mān- ‘delight’, see s.v. māja, to O+E15ss. mondag ‘desire’.

‘to see’, Sid. 105r5 cvai hā śīyi śīyi hira āyiṃde u vajsyāte ṣi’ mīḍe ‘to whom appear bright white things, and he sees, he will die’, Tib. snaŋ-ŋ-čog dkar-por mthoŋ-ba ni hčhi-bar hgyur-ro; Z 4.100 samu kho purra āyäte ūca, Manj. 385 sa khu pūra āye uca ‘just as the moon appears in water’; Z 15.121 kho ūca banhya āyāre trāmä <. .>, Manj. 176 ā khu bahya chāyī uca ṣkaujai āyāre khu byave ‘or as a tree’s shadow in water the saṃskāra factors appear like lightning’; III 29, 41b3 ni jä nä āyāri hugvāna, Manj. 263 nai na ja āyāra hūgvāna ‘they do not appear at all’. Verbal noun III 61.52 ttyāṃ dharma-puṇyāṃ āyāme kiṇa ‘to see
those dharma merits’. Base ā-day- ‘to see’, Av. dai-: di-, see dai- ‘see’, also vūy-, pūy-, and āya ‘official title’.

‘official title, supervisor (?) ’, IV 26.7 ṣi’ pīḍakä pramāṃda hime khu hā āya haṃguṣṭe vistāte, ‘this letter becomes valid when the āya-official affixes his finger’, see SDTV 13 ; parallel II 14, 2b8-9 khuī parramā pyaysīdä ‘ when the parramaa- officials sign’. From ā-dayā- ‘supervisor (?)’, masc. ā-stem, to Av. daya- in paiti.daya- ‘overseer’, to dai- ‘to see’. If the final -a of āya stands for older -ä, the base would be ā-daya-.
‘mirror’, Manj. 246 vasve y(e) āya vīra satv(ā)na āvīda tcīre ‘in a clean mirror, one sees the faces of the beings’, parallel to BS ādarśa-maṇḍale supariśuddhe. See āyäna-‘mirror’.

‘it may be’, conjunctive 3 sing, to ah- ‘be’; 2 sing. Z 2.98 śśäru tsutai ma stātä āye ‘you have well come, do not stand’; 3 plur. Z 4.40 ku va yakṣa-bhavana ne āro ‘where goblin-dwellings do not exist’, BS yakṣa-bhavana-.
‘in a mirror’, see āyäna-.
‘examples’, see āyänaa-.

‘hilarity’, Z 12.75 ka bodhisatvä āyiḍetu näjsaṣḍe apracä, BS saṃcagghati saṃkrīḍate saṃkilikīlāyate auddhatyam dravaṃ prāviṣkaroti ‘if the bodhisattva shows hilarity without cause’. Base kar- ‘to play’, see cognates s.v. tcarke, and hayär-.

‘mirror’, Z 24.491 kye hva’ndi hūdva gva’ haysge patälste ttu mä na vā hvāñita āyärnna cu yīndi ‘what man’s two ears, nostrils (=nose) are cut off, you will not tell this to me what he does with a mirror’, =BS Siks. 47.5 saṃchinna-karṇa-nāsānām ādarśaiṣām kutaḥ priyaḥ, Tib. mi sna daŋ rna-ba bčad-pa-la meloŋ-gi či źig bya. Loc. sing. Z 4.100 āyäña, Z 15.123 ātīña, III 52.96 sa khu āyaña śāma ‘like a face in a mirror’, Manj. 283-4 uce pūra āyañe tcara ‘the moon in water, a face in a mirror’; Manj. 300 khu āyīñai dyāma tcīre ‘like the sight of a face in a mirror ’; Manj. 373 ā tcīra āyeña dette ‘as a face is seen in a mirror’. This is a cliché, as Mahāyāna-sūtrālaṃkāra 11.30 udaka-candra-bimba-sadṛśāḥ and Śikṣ. 261.18 ādarśa-maṇḍale. Without final -a- III 70.105 āyeṃ baña ‘bind on a mirror’ (Rāma’s advice to the monkey); K 28.181-2 khu ja āye spāśa ‘as a mirror appears’, =K 21.6-7. From *ādaina- or *ādayana-; Sogd. ’’δ’yn’k, M.Parth.T. ”dyng, Zor.P. aδvēnak, N.Pers. āēnah, Balōčī ādēnk, Oss. D. ajdänä, I. ajdän, to ā with dai-: di- ‘to see’.

‘example, simile’, Z 19.89 āyänai. Z 19.86 āyīnai, Z 19.91 āyīnau, III 74.201 āyanā vāśā’ṃdä yāṃdä ‘they continually recited examples’, =BS dṛṣṭānta, found in III 29, 44b2 diṣṭānta. From *ā-dayanaka-, see also āyäna-‘mirror’, to base dai- ‘to see’.

‘ground, sole of foot’, SuvO. 56r1 ttere jsa ttye dāta-hvāñei pānu ā’ye<. .>nīmä ‘with forehead I embrace the soles of the feet of this dharma-preacher ’, BS uttamāngena ca tasya dharma-bhāṇakasya bhikṣoḥ pāda-talau pratisaṃhariṣyāmi; SuvO. 56r3 odä vaśiriṃgye śśaṃdye ā’ye, BS yāvad vajramayaṃ pṛthivī-talam upādāya ‘as far as the ground of the adamantine earth’. See also eväte ‘street’, and aya ‘ground’. From āy- (the hook indicating older āyy-), with Av. āi, and N.Pers. xāk ‘dust’. M.Parth.T. ’y’g ‘place’ may be added here. For N.Pers. xāk a derivation from *āhaka- ‘ashes’ is proposed by G. Morgenstierne, NTS 12, 1942, 266, with Parāčī hāγ.
